<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 278, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 294]]<|/det|>
9709/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 341, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[730, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
February/March 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 217, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A fair spinner with 5 sides numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 is spun repeatedly. The score on each spin is the number on the side on which the spinner lands.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 803, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a score of 3 is obtained for the first time on the 8th spin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 395, 186, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 395, 915, 413]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that fewer than 6 spins are required to obtain a score of 3 for the first time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 411, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The time spent by shoppers in a large shopping centre has a normal distribution with mean 96 minutes and standard deviation 18 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a shopper chosen at random spends between 85 and 100 minutes in the shopping centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 655, 523]]<|/det|>
88% of shoppers spend more than \(t\) minutes in the shopping centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 539, 146, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 539, 311, 556]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 539, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) takes the values 1, 2, 3, 4 only. The probability that \(X\) takes the value \(x\) is \(k x(5 - x)\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 653, 139]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\), in terms of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 425, 185, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 425, 363, 444]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{Var}(X) = 1.05.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 425, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 920, 108]]<|/det|> A driver records the distance travelled in each of 150 journeys. These distances, correct to the nearest km, are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 116, 828, 163]]<|/det|>
Distance (km)0-45-1011-2021-3031-4041-60
Frequency12163266204
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 197]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 180, 613, 197]]<|/det|> Draw a cumulative frequency graph to illustrate the data. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 197]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 677, 92]]<|/det|>
For \(30\%\) of these journeys the distance travelled is \(d \text{km}\) or more.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 495, 123]]<|/det|>
Use your graph to estimate the value of \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 380, 186, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 380, 742, 399]]<|/det|>
Calculate an estimate of the mean distance travelled for the 150 journeys.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 74, 905, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the total number of different arrangements of the 11 letters in the word CATERPILLAR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 89, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 330, 186, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 330, 920, 363]]<|/det|>
Find the total number of different arrangements of the 11 letters in the word CATERPILLAR in which there is an R at the beginning and an R at the end, and the two As are not together. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the total number of different selections of 6 letters from the 11 letters of the word CATERPILLAR that contain both Rs and at least one A and at least one L.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> There are 400 students at a school in a certain country. Each student was asked whether they preferred swimming, cycling or running and the results are given in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 116, 734, 184]]<|/det|>
SwimmingCyclingRunning
Female1045066
Male315792
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 201, 366, 217]]<|/det|> A student is chosen at random. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 231, 146, 249]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 231, 195, 249]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 230, 640, 249]]<|/det|> Find the probability that the student prefers swimming. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 231, 920, 249]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 429, 183, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 429, 920, 464]]<|/det|> Determine whether the events ‘the student is male’ and ‘the student prefers swimming’ are independent, justifying your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 445, 920, 464]]<|/det|> [2]
